It is a beautiful day here in Sydney. Before I arrived in Australia, I was in Singapore, where it was also beautiful but incredibly humid. The air felt thick to move through and breathe, but in actuality humid air is less dense then dry air. Derek, tell us about Avogadro's law.
Well, Avogadro came up with the idea that in a given volume of gas at a given temperature and pressure, there will be always the same number of gas particles. Doesn't matter what the gas is, If it's helium or nitrogen or oxygen.
And that holds truth for air which is a mixture of gases. That's right, So, it's got nitrogen and oxygen principally. But if it's humid air, then you replace some of those nitrogens and oxygens with water.
And water is wider than the diatomic nitrogen and oxygen that exists in our atmosphere.
That's right. Oxygen and nitrogen have masses of 32 and 28, whereas water is just 18. Humid air is actually much less dense than dry air. It's lighter and things can move through it more easily. This is especially true when it comes to baseballs. A baseball travels through humid air more easily and further, with the same amount of energy. If air becomes more humid and decreases drag by only five percent that can mean the difference between a fly ball and a home run. This became a problem when indoor baseball stadiums started to play around with the idea of turning on the air conditioning when the rival team came up to bat. Essentially, the air conditioning made the air dryer, therefore thicker and made the rivall team hit baseballs shorter distances.

The word normal, by the way, is homological.
What does that mean?
A homological adjective describes itself. For instance, the word tiny is pretty tiny. It's a small word. The word unhyphenated is unhyphenated. Normal is one of the top 1000 most commonly spoked and written words. The word normal is normal, it describes itself. But there are also words that are heterological ; adjectived that don't describe themselves. For instance, the word misspelled.
Yes well, if you don't misspell it.
If you don't misspell it. What about abbreviated? Ooo. I like that one, too. What about German? Not a German word.
That's a good one. How about monosyllabic? That's heterological because it doesn't describe itself. But polsyllabic? For sure. I especially love just how homological pentasyllabic is.
Yeah, five syllables. That is genius. Well, it's the way words are. The way they normally are. But what about you, are you normal?

Well a common way of defining normal is to say that something about you is normal, if you fall within just one standard deviation of the average for all people. But there are a lot of things about you. You can easily think of, say, 36 different independent variables. Different things to say about yourself. For instance, how tall you are, how many friends you have, how bad your breath is or, say, how often you lie. Now, the statistical probability that you would be normal for all 36 of those different attributes is actually one in a million. Which means, mathematically speaking, it is quite abnormal to be normal. And as always, thanks for watching.

For those who still don't understand The Three Prisoners Problem:

It basically means whoever asks the guard who's going to die in order to reassure himself he is likely not one of the guys to die (because the guard will tell him one of the other guys is chosen to die regardless if the guy who asks is chosen or not), is going to unknowingly increase their chance of being one of the chosen to be killed due to simple mathematic probabilities. In other words, this doesn't make logical sense in any SINGLE scenario you find yourself in; But when accounting for ALL scenarios possible, probability says the guy who you don't know is going to live or die is going to more likely to live than the one who asks the guard in the first place.

Here's a fun paradox: is "heterological" heterological?
If yes: "heterological" is heterological. It describes itself. Heterological words do not describe themselves, therefore "heterological" is not heterological. Contradiction.
If no: "heterological is not heterological. It does not describe itself. Heterological words do not describe themselves, therefore "heterological" is heterological. Contradiction.

And the converse, which I find quite amusing: is "homological" homological?
If yes: "homological" is homological. It describes itself. Homological words describe themselves, therefore "homological" is homological. No contradiction.
If no: "homological" is not homological. It does not describe itself. Homological words describe themselves, therefore "homological" is not homological. No contradiction.

So "heterological" can neither be homological nor heterological, but "homological" can be both. This is called the Grelling-Nelson paradox.

You did describe the montehall problem a little more complicated than it needed to be. Let's assume there are 3 doors in front of you. 1 leads to a jackpot prize. The chances you get it right on your first guess, regardless of which door you pick, are 1/3. If you're already lost then I can't help you. That means the chances you are incorrect becomes 2/3, since there are 3 doors total. If the game show host tells you that one of the doors you didn't pick are wrong, that doesn't change the fact that your first guess is still only has a 1/3 chance of winning. And your odds of losing are still the same at 2/3. Now you're faced with 2 doors, one that has a 1/3 chance of winning, and a 2/3 chance.

Since your first guess was still when the odds were 1/3, your guess's odds don't change when a door get eliminated. Just like if you picked from a 100 doors, your odds would be 1/100 and your chance of losing would be 99/100. If you removed every single door, besides the on you picked and 1 other, labeling all the rejected ones as incorrect, your odds don't increase. It's still your 1/100 vs a 99/100

Is the adjective “heterological” heterological or homological? Well, if it is heterological then it doesn’t describe itself, which means that “heterological” is not heterological, but is homological. That’s a contradiction. On the other hand, if it is homological then it does describe itself, which means that “heterological” is heterological. Again, a contradiction! But how can a word neither describe itself nor not describe itself? We are forced to conclude that the division of words into the apparently mutually exclusive and exhaustive categories of “heterological” and “homological” is itself illogical!

“The distance across St. George's Channel, between Holyhead and Kingstown Harbour, near Dublin, is at least 60 statute miles. It is not an uncommon thing for passengers to notice, when in, and for a considerable distance beyond the centre of the Channel, the Light on Holyhead Pier, and the Poolbeg Light in Dublin Bay. The Lighthouse on Holyhead Pier shows a red light at an elevation of 44 feet above high water; and the Poolbeg Lighthouse exhibits two bright lights at an altitude of 68 feet; so that a vessel in the middle of the Channel would be 30 miles from each light; and allowing the observer to be on deck, and 24 feet above the water, the horizon on a globe would be 6 miles away. Deducting 6 miles from 30, the distance from the horizon to Holyhead, on the one hand, and to Dublin Bay on the other, would be 24 miles. The square of 24, multiplied by 8 inches, shows a declination of 384 feet. The altitude of the lights in Poolbeg Lighthouse is 68 feet; and of the red light on Holyhead Pier, 44 feet. Hence, if the earth were a globe, the former would always be 316 feet and the latter 340 feet below the horizon!” -- Dr. Samuel Rowbotham, *Earth Not a Globe!*

“The lights which are exhibited in lighthouses are seen by navigators at distances at which, according to the scale of the supposed ‘curvature’ given by astronomers, they ought to be many hundreds of feet, in some cases, down below the line of sight! For instance: the light at Cape Hatteras is seen at such a distance (40 miles) that, according to theory, it ought to be nine-hundred feet higher above the level of the sea than it absolutely is, in order to be visible! This is a conclusive proof that there is no ‘curvature,’ on the surface of the sea - ‘the level of the sea,’- ridiculous though it is to be under the necessity of proving it at all: but it is, nevertheless, a conclusive proof that the Earth is not a globe.” -- William Carpenter, *100 Proofs the Earth is Not a Globe*

The key to the prisoner problem is that he can't tell you about your own fate, more emphasis should be put on that. That's the whole reason why the result changes from what you would expect.

If the guard COULD tell you if you die, those would be the possible events with their respective probabilities:

1. You're the one to survive and he tells you Jake dies -> 1/6
2. You're the one to survive and he tells you Kevin dies -> 1/6
3. Jake's the one to survive and he tells you you die -> 1/6
4. Jake's the one to survive and he tells you Kevin dies -> 1/6
5. Kevin's the one to survive and he tells you you die -> 1/6
6. Kevin's the one to survive and he tells you Jake dies -> 1/6

At this point, those events are all equally probable so once he tells you who dies, for instance Jake, you elminate 3. and 4. and you see right away the events where you survive are as likely as those where Kevin survives. You'd have a 1/2 chance of survival. BUT, since he can't tell you if you die, those are the actual events with their probabilities:

1. You're the one to survive and he tells you Jake dies -> 1/6
(1/3 chance you survive * 1/2 he decides to tell you about Jake)
2. You're the one to survive and he tells you Kevin dies -> 1/6
(same thing)
3. Jake's the one to survive and he tells you Kevin dies -> 1/3
(1/3 chance Jake survives*1/1 chance he tells you about Kevin since he can't tell you about your own death)
4. Kevin's the one to survive and he tells you Jake dies -> 1/3
(same thing)

And now, once he reveals Jake dies, you eliminate events 2. and 3. and that leaves you with 1. and 4. possible, where event 4. is twice as likely as event 1., therefore 2/3 chance Kevin survives.


Another way to be convinced about it is: Since the guard couldn't tell you about your own death, you haven't really "survived" anything by not being told you won't die, he couldn't tell you that anyway. Whereas there was a chance he would have said Kevin dies, he "survived" that first pick by not being named, so you would expect that only his chances increase.

Really? that's it, water molecules have lower weight than Nitrogen and Oxygen diatomic molecules, so then humid air is less dense? How about mentioning how much water is there in air at 100% relative humidity, which isn't much, but also happens to be a funciton of temperature. So I'm guessing the effect of air conditioning in baseball stadium for the speed of the ball is more closely related to the density of the gas based on PV=nRT, than on the effect of water molecules, in the end water molecules will only have an effect depending on how many molecules of water there are for molecules of air. Assuming ideal gas (Raoult's law) on a hot day, say 104°F (40°C), water vapour pressure is say 65 mbar (or 0,95 psia). Which means there will be about 6,5% water molecules in air. The molecular weight of air goes down from 28,8 to 28,1, or 2%, but the effect of density (on ideal gas law) is about 7%.
Also water will not entirely behave as an ideal mixture because it is at (for water) hig pressure and low temperature, ideal works best for high pressures and low temperatures. Probably some viral equations would be more accurate. Also viscosity is quite closely related to fluid flow, about the same as density (look at the Reynolds number), but it also depends on the mixture, and mixing rules for that are not quite as easy. Although also viscosity of gases increases with temperature, so maybe the baseball stadium is unexpected, but the explanation was a bit oversimplified for my taste (while it wasn't wrong).

The three prisoners theory, i think is better explained with a card trick i first saw and still is, showcased on the "ScamSchool" youtube channel. I don't remember the name of the video, maybe you will find it if you try, but the tricks is:
There are 3 cards
2 black cards and 1 red card. They are faced down and you are asked to put a finger on the one you believe to be the red card, obviously not knowing whether it is on the left, in the middle or on the right.
Your chances of being right is now 1/3 or (33.33333.......%.
The performer of the trick now reveals one of the 2 left over cards, and it's a black card. Now non-knowing people, or people who are not as big of a freak with numbers as us subscribers to Vsauce, would say that you know have a 1/2 or 50% chance.
Now you are asked if you would like to change your mind and put your finger on top of the other card, or stay.
It seems like it doesn't matter because there is a 1/2 chance either way.
But the trick is, that you in theory always should change your choice of card, because there was a 2/3 chance of you getting the card wrong at the start of the trick. Then the performer reveals the first black card and therefor, there is a greater chance of you having your finger on the other black card, than the red card.

They responded, "Everything being the same or alike."
"Exactly," I said, "And, is everyone the same?"
I was given a resounding, "no."

theres a way you can calculate normal, if you had the statisitics. Take all your attributes and give them distinct definitions and boarders. Then take all of then and break it down into grps of 5. In those grps take the most common attribute of the 5, based on global averages of having that attribute the most. Then take the top of the 5 in each grp, then average those again to see how common it is globally and figure out the percentage of above average and below average traits, and add them up. Repeat this test and average those, for greater accuracy. Its slightly random just based on how average things and probability works in nature, but that formula would hypothetically give you a pretty good mathematical guess at if your close to average, or normal. Assuming traits listed encompass the full scale of possible defined human traits.

Sir Michael, with all due respect, that seems to be an incorrect logic to find your probability of execution in those conditions.
You are mixing two different sample spaces to find your probability.
The actual sample space would comprise of 4 elements with equal weightage as always in a proper sample space, given the condition that the guard won't lie and won't mention the name of the survivor but would mention of a to-be-executed other than you.
Here it is, {"K lives, J mentioned", "you live, J mentioned", "J lives, k mentioned", "you live, K mentioned"}
Since J is mentioned, now there are only two ways that things could be.
{"K lives but J mentioned" or "you live but J mentioned"}
Hence, K (Kevin) and you, now have equal probability of 0.5 .

For anyone with the same confusion: It took me a moment to figure out how Kevin's chances of survival became two-thirds when his slice is still one-third of the whole, but then I realized that I wasn't supposed to be looking at the whole graph anymore. The qualifier is that the guard said Jake dies. By saying that, he eliminates the right half of the graph, because that half represents the probabilities if the guard had said that Kevin dies. He did not name Kevin, so that half is no longer applicable. Kevin's chances of survival in the end are, indeed, two-thirds because it's two-thirds of the remaining left half that represents "the guard said Jake dies". Michael actually makes this clear in his explanation, I just didn't catch it at first.

And to answer the last question posed, no, I am most certainly NOT normal and that's a part of being intrinsically human. People are biologically and psychologically/socially built for complexity. Normality is a construct that we've created to assess other people who are out of alignment with what our brain has experienced before. There are always variants even of labels or identifiers which are just descriptors of what we've agreed upon to name things, groups, people, etc.

Another example is that even physical attributes like race or birthmarks in similar areas and of similar sizes on two people's bodies are variable and given to subjectivity by the person who possesses said attribute. Perspective plays a role and we can only experience our first hand account of externals. Take me for instance. My anxiety/mood shifts affects me deeply while the same stress inducing stimuli, say in a work situation when we have a lot to do, doesn't even phase my coworker. They even thrive on it. Neural pathways in my brain have been formed and triggers set. My brain has made my body accustomed to certain physical symptoms (chest pains, shortness of breath, etc.) when those triggers are "tripped". So the person without anxiety is in THEIR version of "normal" which actually isn't totally "normal" as they also experience stress and anxiety to a lesser extent too in their own life. It's a matter of degrees plus perspective and the interplay between self and "other". It all starts first with the individual perspective of those involved. But the only perspective you can know for certain is yours. Even with deductive reasoning about someone's thoughts, meanings and intentions you may only be half "right" as their feelings and thoughts make then an island. You can logically TRY to guess what someone thinks but you won't know for sure until you ask. And even then things can get misinterpreted or they don't tell the whole story in a clear effective way.

Our brains are, let's say, catalysts. The information within causes an action. Some of which like picking something up are on a subconscious instinctive level. We just pick things up without thinking. We do these things because they are actions that have been proven to produce a result. The old idea, that I heard years ago, goes that you don't think "How do I sit in this chair?" you simply sit down trusting that the chair is stable to sit in. Thoughts breed actions and then causation occurs. We create thoughts and then use those thoughts to garner movement to "make shit happen"! Lol Like a computer program. With a program you execute and then once it's running you have "solved" what is an idea i.e. causation. An idea in an idea. Ideaception! A computer program first started out as an idea in the perspective of one person possibly with colleagues. So our brains are all, metaphorically, computers. They both work in much the same way. We have a thought/desire and we execute based on synapses firing carrying information. We have figurative "pockets" and "compartments" in brain structure much like a computer's designated folders. While it is simplistic to call the brain a computer there are easily categorized similarities. With anxiety my brain decides it wants to run in safe mode ;) Anywho, I've sufficiently rambled enough.

I have two more homological words from the field of linguistics:
Assimilation: when one sound changes to become more like a neighboring sound.
From Lat. ad- "toward" + similis "similar" > adsimilis > assimilis. Assimilation is an example of assimilation!
Reduplication: when a word or syllable is repeated with a change in meaning or aspect. It happens more in other languages http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reduplication
But when you think about it, we could just call it "duplication." Why is the prefix "re-" even there?! It's not an exact copy of another syllable, but I just thinks it's worth the thought.

Dear Vsauce, the solution to the three prisoners problem is only true under this specific condition: The guard HAD to tell you about which of the other prisoners would die, and he was NOT ALLOWED to tell you about yourself.
In this case the information about Jake dying leaves two possibilities: Either you will die, which means he was FORCED to say Jake would die; or Kevin will die as well, in which case he had a choice.
The chances that he was FORCED to say Jake would die are higher than the chances of him having a choice. But in your scenario the guard always had the choice of speaking, so telling you that Jake would die actually leaves you with a 50-50 chance assuming the guard's motives are a mystery.

What are the chances of the guard choosing to tell you in a situation, and the chances of you surviving are 2 different matters. In the situation where he lives, the guard can choose between telling him that J is going to get killed or K. And in the situation where K is going to survive, for J to be chosen as the answer towards M's question, isn't 1/2 anymore, but 1/1, thus twice. What's double isn't the chance of K surviving compared to M's, in the portion selected by vsauce, but the chance of J being chosen as the answer to who's going to die?, by the guard. One is the guard's chances at what he's going to answer, and another is the chances of the people surviving... he mixed them up. In the situation selected by vsauce, where J is said to be the one to get killed, it all gets limited to 2 situations, 1), the one who's going to survive is K, and the guard, with no other choice, said that J is going to die, to M, and 2), M is the survivor, and the guard could've answered either with K or with J, but has chosen J, nevertheless, it being the situation where M survives, thus the chances are still 1 in 2. And the chances themselves are 1 in 2 because you have 2 elements and no clue of which will be chosen, but in reality, the chances are 0 and 100, since it's all already stabilized, just unknown to them, but there's definitely 100 chances for the one already chosen, to survive.

To make it short, in the situation where M is going to survive, for J to be chosen as the answer, the chances are 0.5, while in the situation where K is going to survive, the chances of J being chosen as the answer, is 1, thus double. But, nevertheless, once hearing that J is going to die, it's all up to either K or M dying, thus a chance in 2. 
You were told that J is going to die, and such an answer is twice as possible in the situation where K is going to survive, but the chances didn't actually change, because there were no chances to begin with

Even more confusing is the question of whether heterological is heterological or homological. It can't be either because assuming either produces a contradiction. If we assume heterological is heterological, then it does not describe itself, but we started off by assuming it is heterological so it does describe itself. Likewise, if we assume heterological is homological, then it does describe itself, but if it describes itself, then it is heterological. So how can a word have neither a property or the negation of the same property. But since being heterological is the property of not being homological, then how can a word be niether homological nor not homological?

Another interesting note: The question "is the word homological homological?" is reccursive in nature! The word homological is homological if it describes itself. It describes itself if it is homological. It is homological if it describes itself... etc..

there's a nice paradox with the words 'homological' and 'heterological'.

it arises when you ask "is 'heterological' a heterological word?"

if you answer yes, then that means you're saying it is heterological, but that also means that it describes itself so it can't be heterological.

if you say no, then you're saying it is not heterological, which means that it does not describe itself - but that means that it is heterological.

I think you are wrong on the part of you having a less chance of living than the other person.  It is true that it is human nature for you to assume that you are the one to die but it does not give you a greater chance to die.  You showed that you had two different options with dying but the only reason you had that was because you were the one to ask that.  The truth is that that would be the same case for everyone if they were the one to ask.  Now if this was truly like the Monty Hall problem (which is totally different) then you would be correct because in that problem you are able to switch doors meaning that when you first chose it you had a 2/3 chance of losing and by switching you have a better chance to win.  Now back to the original problem, you have the same variable every time instead of 2/3 to 1/3.

Hi Michael, Today I was in a discussion with some friends about what is art, and we end up talking for a long time about it, specially in the difference of art and craft. my friends droped this on me "With art there is always another layer, something deeper. And indeed this makes some painting or sculptures craft and not art. A statue made to realistically represent a person would be craft and so would be a purely realistic painting, one that is a pure attempt at capturing a moment. Like a photograph, it 's a craft but not an art. (Sometimes phothraphs can be art, if something is captured in a way that makes it ambigues or when it is used as a metaphor)". So I argue to know "if it is the "artist" that gives the multiple layers of ambiguity or metaphor to his work or is some else that finds them and so declares it art. I ask this because many now famous artist died unappreciated by their society and is only now and though our eyes that they became relevant. My point and question is: wasn't the extra layers already there? how did they go unseen if it is so obvious to us now? is art a universal constant or something dictated by each person or group of humans?". for the moment I'm really caught up in this and I thought it can be a great topic for one of your videos. bye

You should upload a video about what would happen if a motorboat went through molasses because it would have an extremely counterintuitive result. A lot of people have the misconception that a motorboat is resisted mainly by the viscosity of water rather than by turbulence. It should also be explained that for an object of a given shape, the speed it must reach to be resisted by quadratic resistance varies as the reciprocal of the viscosity and as the reciprocal of the size. Having shown that, it should then be shown that if there are 2 motorboats both going the same speed gradually accelerating one in molasses and one in water, once the one in water reaches the speed where it starts being resisted by turbulence, its resistance will start varying quadratically with speed catching up to the amount of resistance the one in molasses is resisted by and once it does so, the one it molasses will also start being resisted by quadratic resistance and be pretty much tied in the amount of resistance for all higher speeds. It should also be shown from what the viscosity of molasses is and the size and speed of a motorboat that for something going that fast, it will be resisted about that same amount as it would by water.

The thing is that your location always is related to a reference point. For example our whole solar system also rotates around the middle of our galaxy, but our galaxy also moves. So if you stand still, there are many possibilities to describe your speed. You could say you do not move at all, or you move with the speed of our earth rotating and so on. It's all a matter of the point of view.

Fun Fact: This rule does NOT apply to light. Light has always the same speed, independed of the reference point. If you understand those two things, you understood the bases of the theory of relativity.

I get the point about "it's abnormal to be normal" but let's look at it more closely.

I think a better definition would be to say that most, or a large percentage, of your attributes are within the norm. By this definition most of us ARE, in fact, normal. Keeping the 1 standard deviation definition, there is a ~66% chance that at most 12 of your traits are normal, so a 2/3 chance that at least 2/3 of you is normal.

But 1 standard deviation defines 1 out of 3 people as not normal, so only 2 of 3 are "normal" and that doesn't sound very intuitive. Also, I typically hear 2 standard deviations instead of 1 as defining normalcy, so 1 out of 20 people will be out of the norm.

Here the odds of being normal in everything are about 1 in 5, not 1 in a million. And the probability that you are at least 92% normal is about 92%.So...it IS abnormal to be completely normal, but it's not too weird to be within the norm for most things.

Linguistics tidbit: the word "calque" is a loanword, and the word "loanword" is a calque.
A loanword is taken directly from another language with very little or no translation. A calque is a word taken from another language and then translated literally in order to have the same meaning.

Some food for thought about the conversation about homological and heterological words @ 6:51 (which i am shocked that you didn't mention) is the question of whether Homological is itself a homological word, and if Heterological is itself a heterological word.  After some careful consideration you find that you reach a paradox, equivalent to a famous one known as Russell's Paradox.  If heterological were in fact a heterological word, it would not describe itself... but that is the definition of being a heterological word so.. it does but it doesn't...  On the flipside, if heterological was not a heterological word, it would not describe itself.. but, then that would mean that it is heterological.. so it isn't but it is...

I noticed some people in the comments did not understand the paradox so I would like to try to explain it.

The guard cannot say anything about Micheal, and he cannot say who will live. What that means is if Jake lives, then he must say that Kevin will die, and which means Micheal dies. If Kevin lives, then he must say Jake will die, and which means Micheal will also die. But, if Micheal lives, he cannot say whether if he lives or dies, so he can say either Jake or Kevin will die.

Mathematically speaking, normally the equation is that Micheal has a 1 in 3 chance to live. Because Jake will die, that makes Micheal have a 1 in 2 chance to die because Jake is removed the equation. The contradiction is if Micheal lives, the guard has a choice of picking between Jake and Kevin, meaning Micheal has twice as much of a chance to die. If Kevin were to live, and Micheal could not be mentioned, that would remove Jake from the equation, making Kevin have a chance of 1 in 2. If Jake were to live, and Micheal could not be mentioned, that would remove Kevin from the equation, having him to also have a chance of 1 in 2. If Micheal lives, then either person can be mentioned, meaning they are not removed from the equation.

If it was said prisoner B was going to die, the chances of survival for prisoner A and C both increase from that point on. Once stated that prisoner B will be one of those murdered, they remain part of the statistic (2/3 will be murdered), but no longer play a part in predicting the outcome. Originally, the lack of information given to the prisoners would lead them to predicting either a scenario in which their chances of survival are 1 out of 3 if a survivor is chosen and the remaining prisoners are murdered, OR first 2 out of 3, then 1 out of 2, for a final survival rate of 1 out of 3, again, if victims are chosen at random one at a time. But knowing that one person will be murdered, doesn't change the outcome of the next random event. If you flip a coin and it lands tails up, then you flip the coin again there is still a 50% chance it will land tails up again. Everyone wants to say "it's less likely to get tails twice in a row" and sure, that is true, but the question isn't "What is the likelihood of getting tails twice in a row?" the question is "What is the probability of this next coin toss being tails?" Statistics, probability, it's all weird.

Normal – I can remember reading a science fiction short story some fifty or so years ago (in my day, TV was called books).
The story took place on a huge interstellar, multi-generational space ship approaching the end of its thousand(s) year trip.
One of the “laws” on the ship was that anyone born who was more than one standard deviation from the average of the current population of the ship was to be “recycled”.
The average of the current population, at this point in the story, was highly mutated from “normal” human.
Therefore, someone who was “normal” was outside the one standard deviation and subject to “recycling” i.e. execution.
The story was written to show the difference between average and normal.
 
Average or even median is dependent on its “sample”.
Normal is dependent on a “norm”.
 
For humans, I’m aware of (at least) two “norms” for what it means to be human.
Christians would consider Jesus of Nazareth the “norm” for what it means to be human.
Mohammedans would consider Muhammad that “norm”.

@Julia Mak You have no idea how much time it took to find a way to reply to your previous comment, gosh I hate the Google+ integration. While I was done with a test, my french teacher (I study in the french system, he's also a philosophy teacher though) gave me a paper on the Russel's paradox as he knows that I'm fond of maths in general and he likes to tease at me that it is imperfect any way he can :P Anyway, we discussed it and I told him that, as I explained, the historical context was different, as the definition of sets in the set theory was unclear on that specific point at the time, because mathematicians were too busy discovering more and more properties and consequences rather than building a strong base for the theory itself. It was a mistake that was corrected, as such Russel's paradox is no longer relevant today, although I notice philosophy enthusiasts like to study it, still, for some reason. I'm not anti-philosophy, very far from that, I just criticize the fact that some people analyze so-called "paradoxes" when they are simply the consequence of mistakes and ambiguity, they theoretically do not exist. I'll use the first sentence you posted "Well, in philosophy, we seek to find theories that best describes our intuitions". The word here, is seek, I find that too vague. How can you possibly stumble on anything relevant if you merely wander aimlessly waiting for something to pop in front of you. I prefer the way of maths, you discover a logical property, and derive consequences and other properties from logical reasoning and thinking. And if you somehow discover something else without any basis, mathematicians will never accept it as a truth until you undeniably prove it. I mean, it is a far more efficient way to remove all doubt rather than to write essays and books about something that you will never be able to possibly completely convince someone of :) I hope I cleared my point of view on the matter. But if you have more to add, I'll be more than happy to hear it!

36 attributes, assuming they are uncorrelated, would be quite difficult for most people to come up with. And really, anything within 2 standard deviations is usually considered normal, so, really, to be considered normal you'd need to look at 269 completely uncorrelated variables to reach that 1/1,000,000 chance. It only takes 13 variables to fall to 50%, and interestingly, at 58 variables you have a 1/20 chance of being completely normal. But being one of the 5% makes you ABnormal. One of the things about usual time travel logic used in films and comic books that always struck me as particularly silly was that of space and how it relates to itself. As you see in Back to the Future (to cite the most known example) time is separate from space not in how it changes over time but in its position, so to speak. It's almost as if the person (and objects) travelling through time are laced to that specific spot of Earth, instead of that specific point of the Universe (in which case travelling through time would make you appear on a different date but stranded in who knows where somewhere around our galaxy). That's why I wondered especially in relation to possible short-film plots... whether or not certain positions of the Earth in space would be cyclic and you could calculate where to be (and in what day and hour) to end up in a specific year and place whether it's in the past or future (say you want to go to Hill Valley on November 5th of 1955, you'd have to go to a very specific spot in China on July 24th at 15:32, which is the time and place where the Earth's position would coincide).
But it turns out Michale just blew it for me: the Earth will never again be where it was.

"The word homological is itself homological - but what about the word heterological? Does the word heterological apply to itself or not? If it does not apply to itself then the term is heterological, which means that it does, after all apply to itself. On the other hand, if we say that the word applies to itself, then it is homological and not heterological, which means that it does not apply to itself. No matter which assumption we start with, we end up with the opposite in the end, going around in an endless circle of obscure words. This is also known as Grelling's Paradox. "

Isolating a 'point' in space is a dizzying thought. If you chose a spot in say, an aircraft hangar, you could say it is x from the floor, y from the side and z from the end.
But if there are no fixed points to work from, as in an apparently infinite universe, how do you find your point again?
You could work backwards to the time you decided WHEN the point was, but where is it actually?
As the earth is moving around the sun, and the sun is moving relative to the galaxy and the galaxy is moving relative to other galaxies, which are all moving in different directions, the point doesn't have any specific reference.....

So since Micheal's chances are still 1 in 3, Kevin's are increased to 2 in 3.

I think there is a way to roughly calculate how much have you travelled through the universe. Our Sun is moving at 200 km/s around the Milky Way, and the Milky Way is moving at around 600 km/s, so..
Y[amount of years you have been living]365.25[days per year]*24[hours per day]*60[minutes per hour]*60[seconds per minute](600[speed of Milky Way, km/s] +- 200[speed of Sun around the center of the Milky Way, best/worst case, respectively] (I don't account for the Earth's movement around the Sun and Earth's rotation because i don't think they'll really affect the final result.
And that gives us that you have travelled between Y*12 623 040 000 and Y*18 934 560 000 km, where Y is your age.
So, being 19 years old, I've travelled between between 239 837 760 000 and 359 756 640 000 km through the universe 0_o

The problem with the prisoner paradox is the same as with the Monty Hall problem: both that the mathematics involved are counter-intuitive, but also that the problem is almost universally misrepresented. It is not stated, explicitly or implied, that the guard (or Monty) will always say and do what they do regardless of the setting. With that assumption the conclusion you draw is correct, but that assumption goes unsaid, and is not self-evident.

Calling out the conclusion. If someone were to be normal, then they wouldn't be normal in every category, they would have to be normal within enough of the categories of normality to be within one standard deviation. Most people would be within one standard deviation. So most people are normal. In fact his conclusion is contradictory to what normal means, since to be 100% in all categories wouldn't be normal, it would be extraordinary. No one who is normal is expected to behave or possess perfect characteristics. Normality includes insufficiency, flaws, and irregularities, otherwise you would be perfect, and therefore not normal. 

Let's say it's 6 categories for one standard deviation. Then most people would be normal within 30-36 of 36 categories. And 30 out of 36 being normal sounds pretty damn normal to me.

Most people wouldn't be "normal" if it for example turned out that one standard deviation was something like 19 categories, because then you'd have someone who's more than 50% out of sync with humanity, and that would definitely not be normal.  Of course anyone that knows the basics of normal distribution knows the central limit theorem. An average of averages from the same population will produce a normal distribution. Most people are invariably normal, and this includes the minor flaws or outlying aspects of them. This is a necessity of genetic propagation. If we were too diverse, we wouldn't be mutually compatible, and would then no longer be the same species.

That last idea was a bit iffy.
Of course it is rather unlikely to be normal in 36 ways at once. However, that's a rather sharp point to look at. It's not much unlike saying flipping 36 coins which all land on 1 is rather unlikely / abnormal. However, any other sequence of coin flips of that length, if you just look at that one single sequence, is just as unlikely. And yet, one of those possibilities is the case.
The improbability stems from specifying a single exact sequence as "all ones" or "all zeros" are. If you don't care about order, so you just ask for "three zeros", then, of course you'll get higher probabilities.

A more sensible method of defining normality would be to take those 36 variables and take the expected value and standard deviation of 36 coin flips with according bias. If you fall on an interval one standard deviation within the expected value, you'll be normal. If you land there more often, you are "supernormal" and if you land there more rarely, you are "subnormal" or "abnormal".

Assuming complete independence (which is unlikely in itself), that would mean roughly 21-27 ones out of 36. - 60.5% - 76.0%. So as long as you are normal in about 3/5 - 3/4 of the cases, you'll be normal. Anything above that starts becoming a bit spookily normal - e.g. "supernormal".
In the limit of infinitely many variables, anything that deviates from about 68.3% will seem abnormal. If you were able to be tested in infinitely many independent tests, it would be infinitely unlikely that you'd be more often normal than that. (Or less often for that matter)

It's true that we are moving at some certain speed through the solar system, but the important thing to realise is that you always have to pick a reference point. Either you look at it from earth's perspective, the sun's, the milky way's, our local astronomical cluster, etc.

There's no correct way of looking at it, because each of them is relative. So, saying "it's wrong to say you were born in X" is wrong, because you were actually born there. There's nothing scientifically wrong about picking the reference frame of the earth in that situation.

For the people who did not get the guard problem.
k=killed, s=saved, (you), [guard info]
There is 3 options:
(k),k,s   1/3
(k),s,k   1/3
(s),k,k   1/3
Your chances of living are 1/3.
You already knew that one of the other prisoners is always going to die, so whatever the guard tell you won't get your chances of living higher or lower, it will still remain 1/3.
So the remaining chance of living will add up to the other person from 1/3 to 2/3, that is because they were the subjects in question, not you.
(k),[k],s  1/3  
(k),s,[k]  1/3    
(s),k,[k]  1/6  or (s),[k],k 1/6
As you can see, the person that the guard did not mention now has 2/3 to live, but you still have 1/3.

I disagree with the circle chart. If the inner circle represents the possible outcomes of who lives and the outer circle represents what the guard can tell you based on what those outcomes will be and the restrictions on what he can tell you (which I think is important; the outer circle is what the guard can tell you, not what the guard does tell you), then I fail to see how him telling you that Jake will die removes your chance of living from the side of the chart where he can tell you that Kevin will die; because there are no circumstances that would force the guard to name Kevin or Jake as one of the ones to die, in the circumstance that you live, it shouldn't divide that section of the chart. It's alternative. Once one of them is named to die, it removes the possibility of the other one being named as well (since he can't tell you the fate of both of them), ergo the whole top section of the chart that you divided up is EITHER he tells you Jake dies OR he tells you Kevin dies, not split between the two. Another way to look at it, if you live, telling you that Jake dies does not remove the possibility of him instead having told you in the first place that Kevin would die, thus it does not remove the section of the chart that represents you living where he can (not does) tell you Kevin lives, so that half of your chances of living you cut out still exists. If the guard tells you that Jake will die, the possibilities that exist then are all of those where Jake dies, not just those where the guard tells you that Jake dies. If he tells you Jake will die, then any outcome where Jake dies is viable. If you live and Kevin and Jake die and the guard tells you that Kevin will die, that is still an outcome wherein Jake dies, therefore that outcome still needs to be factored in.

Interesting fact:  The word "normal" comes from the Latin word "normalis."  Normalis translates into "carpenter square."  When the word first came to English, it meant something that is in a 90° angle.  All of this is why the term "Square" is a very common synonym for "normal."
It wasn't until the late 1800s/early 1900s it got its current definition.

How could a non-physical thing stay attached the same point on the earth's surface when Earth is rotating and flying around the sun, which flies around the galaxy? In order to stay anchored, it would have to interact physically with this world, making it subject to physical laws, so the whole concept of the nonphysical breaks down. Otherwise, all "ghosts" are left far behind us in space. Anything that can pass through walls could not be contained, nor carried along by a physical container or gravity. But if it does interact with the physical world, then it could not have "ghostlike" properties. One can't have it both ways.

The Three Prisoner problem is not as complex as you say it is. Let's say that the names were chosen out of a hat. If you are told that Jake's name was one of the two chosen to be executed, then either you or Kevin will be safe. Kevin may not know that Jake was chosen, but the possibility that both you and Kevin will be executed is now gone. The possibility that both Jake and Kevin die is now greater because you already know Jake is going to die. The possibility that you and Jake die is now greater for that same reason. There were only three original combinations, each one as likely as the next. What the guard tells you eliminates one, but the other two stay equal.

I think that the idea of individual "normality" falls apart once you start to try and look at it as something that can be measured quantitatively. In my mind, normal (as most people mean it) is used to describe an individually perceived consistency with more commonly occurring traits, and this perception is going to suffer from a kind of self-blindness.

If you look at your life and find that you look, act, and live in ways that is in line with what you perceive as being most common in your surroundings you will think of yourself as normal; however, if you see something or many things about yourself that do not align with your perception of what is around you, you will think of yourself as being abnormal. This is really a matter of perception and juxtaposition.

One person's normal is another person's strange, and is greatly controlled by what someone focuses on. God now I'm rambling, and procrastinating, I should be grading papers right now...

About the where you were born thing, the concept of somewhere being the same place at two different times doesn't make sense at all.

Since Galileo we have known that there is no preferred inertial reference frame. So that me and my friend can be floating through space by each other and both consider ourselves to be stationary and the other moving. There is just no fact about which of us is moving absolutely.

Accepting that if someone is stationary they remain at the same place for all times we arrive at a problem. Me and my friend float by each other and we cross paths at some place and time. Then we continue on and arrive at different places. But since we are both able to be considered stationary these are the same place.

Places do not exist through time.

here's something interesting that was never mentioned: heterological is both heterological and homological. think about it... if it describes itself, it is homological, however, by being homological, by describing itself, it is not heterological. but if it is not heterological, then it doesn't describe itself, meaning it is no longer homological, instead being heterological. but, once again, if it is heterological, it describes itself, making it homological and therefore not heterological.
